title: Behaviour of `autosave` associations has changed on edge
body:
### Steps to reproduce

This script has different output between `7-2-stable` and `main`:

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

require "bundler/inline"

gemfile(true) do
  source "https://rubygems.org"

  # gem "rails"
  # gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "7-2-stable"
  gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main"

  gem "sqlite3", "~> 1.4"
end

require "active_record"
require "minitest/autorun"
require "logger"

# This connection will do for database-independent bug reports.
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection(adapter: "sqlite3", database: ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Base.logger = Logger.new(STDOUT)

ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :users, force: true do |t|
    t.integer :address_id
    t.timestamps
  end

  create_table :addresses, force: true do |t|
    t.text :country
    t.timestamps
  end
end

class User < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :address, autosave: true
end

class Address < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :user
end

class BugTest < Minitest::Test
  def test_bad
    user = User.create!(address: Address.new(country: "USA"))

    user.create_address(country: "Australia")

    assert_equal "Australia", User.find(user.id).address.country
  end

  def test_fine
    user = User.create!(address: Address.new(country: "USA"))

    user.address.update!(country: "Australia")

    assert_equal "Australia", User.find(user.id).address.country
  end
end

```

### Expected behavior

Both tests should pass.

### Actual behavior

`test_bad` fails on `main` but not `7-2-stable`.

Admittedly, it's not a good way of writing the code, because the "USA" `Address` record is orphaned as a result. But I think this is still a regression.

### System configuration
**Rails version**: `main`

**Ruby version**: 3.2
